title: How and why to disable Wi-Fi Assist on Apple's iOS 9
text:
How and why to disable Wi-Fi Assist on Apple's iOS 9 Apple's new pink (rose gold) iPhone 6S Apple's new iPhone comes in four colors, including pink (rose gold). (Apple event) Comments 
Apple's new mobile operating system iOS 9 was unveiled last week with an array of new features. One of those additions, however, could end up being expensive for people with limited data plans. 
The new "Wi-Fi Assist" automatically switches the phones from Wi-Fi to a cell network if the Wi-Fi signal is weak. The new setting, designed to limit buffering while online, is turned on automatically when a phone is updated to iOS 9 but it could lead to people unwittingly using up their data plan when the network switch occurs. 
So what can you do to avoid the costs? Turn off Wi-Fi Assist in the Mobile Data settings screen. Here's how to do that, from phonearena.com. 
1. Go to settings menu. Once there, tap on cellular 2. Once inside cellular, scroll all the way down to the bottom. Right beneath the apps list, you will see Wi-Fi Assist. It's enabled by default. 3. Flip the Wi-Fi Assist off.Turning the Wi-Fi Assist off should prevent a nasty surprise â€“ at least due to data usage from the switch - at the end of the month.
